title: Spare Times

body: As the snow deepened Sunday and Monday, roughly 100 front-line 911 operators in Downtown Brooklyn fielded tens of thousands of calls, struggling to sort the true emergencies from an ocean of concerns about stranded cars, twisted ankles and people simply stuck in their homes. The result was frayed nerves and growing exhaustion, as call after call
title: 'It Was Hell': Weary Dispatchers Describe Flood of 911 Calls During Storm

body: The end of her life merited a 19-word sentence in a newspaper article about the first 10 killings on Jan. 1, 1987. She was the eighth killing recorded that day. There was no mention of her name or her age. Nearly 24 years later, posters with her photograph and the small details of her death have popped up in subway stations and stores in Sunset
title: A Cold Case, and Hope, Is Revived

author: Jim Dwyer is on leave.
body: On the third day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tried on empathy. Sort of. Our mayor comes with great reluctance to ''I feel your pain'' moments, calling to mind a Park Avenue dowager donning a sack cloth. But there he was Tuesday, standing in one of those emergency management headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn, speaking of sanitation workers laboring
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; For a Snow-Crippled City, a Morsel of Humble Pie From the Mayor

body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History Through Aug. 15, ''Brain: The Inside Story,'' an interactive exhibition that blends technology, history and neuroscience. On view through Jan. 2 are the Origami Holiday Tree, with ornaments that reflect museum displays, and ''Race to the End of the Earth,'' an exhibition on Antarctic
title: Spare Times

body: FOR nearly all of her postcollegiate life, Allison Castillo lived in fully furnished sublets. There were a few years when she actually owned a large piece of furniture -- a bed -- but ''it was given to me by a friend who was moving out of town,'' she said. So that didn't quite count. Ms. Castillo, who comes from the suburbs of Schenectady,
title: THE HUNT; Goodbye, Other People's Furniture

body: MR. FIGARO'S barber shop has been a mainstay of Avenue Z in Brooklyn since it was opened in 1977 by Jerry May, the singing barber. Mr. May always drew a crowd as he clipped and crooned imitations of Pavarotti, Jolson, Sinatra and others. Mr. May closed the shop in June after a partial ceiling collapse. Then a minor stroke left him blind in one eye.
title: OPEN & SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: IT was a school night in November, and a ragtag band of self-appointed biologists was trolling the Web for discount lab equipment, the way some people scan Gilt for designer deals. Coming across a new NanoDrop Spectrophotometer, a device used to measure quantities of DNA, they perked up. ''Ooh, that one's 30 percent off,'' said Sung Won Lim, 22,
title: Turning Geek Into Chic

body: This week the miser offers a mixed bag of cheap events to help get you fired up or chilled out, depending on your holiday needs. Like ''A Very Yoga Christmas.'' If you're thinking of chanting and chai tea, think again. Not being a huge fan of the holidays, Joe Yoga created this show, now in its third year, to reflect his sense of family: the
title: Weekend Miser

body: MOSCOW -- Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who owns the New Jersey Nets basketball team, rolled out another pet project on Monday: Russia's first gas-electric hybrid car. It is called the Yo, for the Russian letter ''Ã«,'' and it can use either gasoline or natural gas to generate its electric power. Proponents say the Yo makes use of
title: Billionaire Backs a Gas-Electric Hybrid Car to Be Built in Russia

body: A plan by the New York Fire Department to allay severe budget cuts by charging motorists up to $490 to respond to accidents and car fires has touched off blistering criticism and calls for the City Council to outlaw the policy. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, nevertheless, is embracing the new fee proposal, which City Hall officials said would begin on
title: Planned Fire Dept. Fees For Motorists Criticized

body: Diana Brown has been sickly since childhood, suffering a variety of mysterious and disabling problems that often kept her home from school. She remembers a doctor telling her mother not to get too attached to her, because she would not be around very long. Today, at 56, Ms. Brown has systemic lupus, which was diagnosed when she was in her 40s, and
title: NEEDIEST CASES; Fighting the Pain and the Paperwork, and Regaining a Place to Call Home

body: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations for the holiday season at churches, synagogues and concert halls in New York City, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Houses of worship accept donations.) Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts. Friday CARNEGIE HALL Holiday songs with Brian Stokes
title: O Tidings of Comfort and Joy, Comfort and Joy

body: For her first assignment of the school year, Verona Gill, a $100,000-a-year special education teacher whom the city is trying to fire, sat around education offices in Lower Manhattan for two weeks, waiting to be told what to do. For her second assignment, she was sent to a district office in the Bronx and told to hand out language exams to anyone
title: Facing Firing, Teachers Still In Idle Limbo

body: Ms. Ramirez, 63, is the president of Halstead Property, a residential brokerage that, along with the luxury brokerage Brown Harris Stevens, is owned by Terra Holdings. Halstead represents about four dozen developments in the New York area, including the Toren in downtown Brooklyn and 865 U.N. Plaza. Q The year is coming to a close. How will we end
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Diane M. Ramirez

body: A trickle of shoppers wandered the repaved sidewalks of the Fulton Street Mall one recent evening, under new streetlamps, a model the city calls the ''Fulton Pole,'' and freshly planted Kentucky coffee trees. They walked past the pizzeria that will close soon to make way for a Shake Shack, Danny Meyer's hyper-popular hamburger chain, and past the
title: An Eclectic Shopping Hub Wonders What's Next

body: International FINANCIAL CRISES SHAKE German Trust in Euro Zone Chancellor Angela Merkel has tried to assure business leaders and investors that Germany is committed to a strong, stable euro, while at the same time assuring the German public that it is time to get tough with investors and demand that other euro zone nations fix their finances. It is
title: Inside the Times

body: As subjects for musical comedy go, it would be hard to fathom anything less promising than the legal intricacies of the concept of eminent domain. Or, for that matter, the socioeconomic diversity of the crazy quilt of Brooklyn neighborhoods. The great Stephen Sondheim himself might find it tricky work to make lyrical magic of the relationships
title: THEATER REVIEW | 'IN THE FOOTPRINT'; A Brooklyn Civics Lesson, Offered in Word and Song

body: The Bloomberg administration is set to move ahead on Tuesday with plans to create a large-scale bike-sharing program that would make hundreds or even thousands of bicycles available for public use throughout New York City -- a nimble, novel form of mass transit that has already become mainstream in cities like Washington and Paris. The city plans
title: City to Solicit Proposals on Bike Sharing

title: Spare Times

body: New York University abandoned plans to build the tallest tower in Greenwich Village on Thursday after the influential architect I. M. Pei made his opposition known, and is now proposing to build a shorter but bulkier building on a different site. N.Y.U. had sought approval from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to add a 38-story tower to
title: N.Y.U. Scraps Plan to Add 38-Story Tower to Complex

body: When David Black contemplated moving his 21-year-old literary agency to a new office space this summer, he had one nagging worry: the East River. ''Would that be a problem?'' Mr. Black said, pointing to the river from his 27th-floor office window, which boasts sweeping views of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan skyline. ''Is water a barrier to
title: No Bridge Too Far: Agents Move To Brooklyn

body: ''So there's ULURP,'' begins the second song in a new musical about Brooklyn. ''ULURP is the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure/Which required community involvement and public review/Of all kinds of New York City land-use projects.'' If this seems like something you might read in the notes of a community board meeting, that's because it is. The song
title: In Brooklyn, Dramatizing Real Discord

body: AS a born-and-bred Manhattanite, Kirsten Abrams never considered living in any other borough. She and her partner, Jane Bishop, who is from Long Island, lived for the last four years at Le Rivage, an Art Deco rental building on West Street, just north of Battery Park. They paid $2,500 a month. When they moved there from the Upper East Side, the
title: THE HUNT; Building to Buyers: 'Here I Am'

body: There was a death in the family. The family is huge, extending wherever French and English are sung. Many of us are not related at all, but consider ourselves honorary fifth cousins or some such, by virtue of loving their music. Now a close friend of that family is running in the New York City Marathon, to honor Kate McGarrigle, whose own race
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Lost Notes Will Linger as Footsteps Fall

body: A PHOTOGRAPH of an Army cadet pilot hangs on a wall in the apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where William and Lucille Harris have lived nearly their entire married life. He wears a bomber jacket, goggles pushed up over his hair and a milewide smile. The fledgling pilot must have been a heartbreaker; not surprisingly, an insurance company clerk a
title: HABITATS | PARK SLOPE; Finders, Keepers

body: I had barely finished signing in at the Expectant Mother Care counseling center in Downtown Brooklyn when a staff member ushered me into a darkened room for a sonogram. As we both watched the flickering image of what looked more or less like a tadpole, she called my attention to every anatomical detail, from eyes and nose to hands and toes. Staring
title: CITY CRITIC; A Hidden Minefield at Pregnancy Centers

body: THE phone calls roll into Andrew M. Cuomo's campaign headquarters all day long, each one a tinder box: Why do no African-Americans live in Westchester? How dare Mr. Cuomo take his daughters to a gay pride parade? Does Mr. Cuomo know that hydrofracking will destroy upstate New York, and what is his position? Now someone on the line -- he is 81 and
title: THE LOYAL TROOPS; The Loyal Troops: Working the phones for Cuomo, and remaining calm under fire.

body: The faces were the same, but the body language could not have been more different. Eight years ago, Bill Clinton stood alongside Andrew M. Cuomo, bucking him up as Mr. Cuomo made a humbling exit from the primary for governor of New York with assurances from Mr. Clinton that his political career was far from over. On Wednesday, the former president
title: Cuomo's Former Boss Is Also an Admirer

body: Jay H. Walder, the imposingly tall 51-year-old chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, pointed approvingly at the giant flat-screen television installed this month near an entrance to the Atlantic Avenue subway station in Downtown Brooklyn. The screen presented a real-time, color-coded guide to what was happening on every line in the
title: THE SUBWAY ISSUE; Strapped: A Bumpy Year

body: THE B AND Q SUBWAY STATIONS at Neck Road and Avenue U on the Brighton Line are to reopen on Monday after partial closings since mid-2008, and it is not hard to gauge how riders feel about it. Last week at the Avenue U station, a sign offering apologies for delays was defaced with a rebuttal: ''Apology Not Accepted.'' The closings are part of an
title: OPEN & SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: The graffiti has been replaced by advertising. The tokens have been replaced by MetroCards. But the subway preachers are a constant. They were there before I was born and will likely be there after I die -- unless, of course, their occasional prophecy of the exact date that the world will end turns out to be accurate. Some hand out leaflets quietly
title: Speaking of God, As Souls Hurry By

body: Sensing a sea change in the way contemporary-art collectors are getting their information -- more from fairs than galleries, museum exhibitions or biennials -- two curators from the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., have set themselves a Herculean challenge: in just five days they plan to tour Art Basel Miami Beach, some 20 other fairs
title: INSIDE ART; A Museum Exhibition Assembled on the Fly

body: With the long-awaited opening this week of a Barneys Co-op branch in Brooklyn, the borough's Atlantic Avenue -- long a shoppers' mecca of independent designer boutiques and well-trod antiques stores (with the occasional bail-bond agent thrown into the mix) -- gets a powerful magnet store that's sure to draw even more of the city's shopaholics to
title: BROWSING; Next Stop, Brooklyn

body: An emergency medical technician accused of not helping a pregnant woman who collapsed and later died was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court on Tuesday on a misdemeanor charge of official misconduct. Prosecutors in the Brooklyn district attorney's office said the technician, Melisa Jackson, was at an Au Bon Pain restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn in
title: E.M.T. Accused of Failing to Help Pregnant Woman Is Arraigned in Her Death

Based on the books by Katharine Holabird and Helen Craig and the PBS series ''Angelina Ballerina the Next Steps,'' the show
title: Spare Times

body: Immigrant news organizations, like their mainstream cousins, have been closely tracking local political campaigns. In the following excerpts, El Diario La Prensa celebrates Francisco Moya's victory in the Democratic primary for a Queens Assembly seat, while a Pakistani Web site and the Polish daily Nowy Dziennik report on apathy and feelings of
title: NEW YORK WORLD; Excerpts From the Ethnic Press

author: PAUL AUSTER is a novelist. This short story later became the movie ''Smoke.''
body: I heard this story from Auggie Wren. Since Auggie doesn't come off too well in it, at least not as well as he'd like to, he's asked me not to use his real name. Other than that, the whole business about the lost wallet and the blind woman and the Christmas dinner is just as he told it to me. Auggie and I have known each other for close to 11 years
title: OP-ED CONTRIBUTOR; DEC. 25, 1990: A Brooklyn Story

body: TO the chagrin of many renters in New York City, the balance of power in the rental market has tipped back toward landlords -- if not far enough for landlords to start celebrating quite yet. At the beginning of the year, renters could demand and receive a month of free rent and maybe even get the landlord to pay their broker's fees. Those
title: Advantage, Landlord

body: Like many New Yorkers, the people of Brooklyn Heights have something of a love-hate relationship with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. On the one hand, the highway is the bane of the neighborhood, carrying trucks whose startling rumbles often wake the sleeping, and spewing dust and fumes onto leafy streets named Cranberry, Pineapple and Willow. But
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS JOURNAL; As Aging B.Q.E. Faces Reconstruction, Ideas Turn to Tunnels

body: A complex four-team trade that would send Carmelo Anthony to New Jersey -- and renew the dormant rivalry between the Nets and the Knicks -- was under discussion Friday as N.B.A. teams prepared to open training camps. Under the proposed deal, the Nets would obtain Anthony, one of the league's brightest stars, from the Denver Nuggets. The Nets would
title: Nets Discuss 4-Team Deal to Get Anthony From Nuggets

body: 'THE MAGIC ORANGE TREE' CELEBRATION When Diane Wolkstein listened to news reports after the January earthquake in Haiti, she continually heard references to that country's extreme poverty. She found the descriptions heartbreaking, she said, because in her view Haiti has at least one source of great wealth. ''It's not poor in culture,'' said Ms.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: New Yorkers who speak little or no English are being illegally denied interpreters in transit court, often leaving them at a disadvantage as they try to fight summonses for littering, fare beating and other violations, the New York Civil Liberties Union charged on Thursday. In a letter to New York City Transit, the civil rights group said the
title: Transit Court Should Have Translators, Group Says

body: An experimental music organization has plans to renovate a dilapidated 600-seat theater space near the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a move that some hope will re-energize an effort to build a cultural district around the academy in downtown Brooklyn. The music group, Roulette Intermedium, which has been based in Manhattan since 1978, signed a 20-year
title: SQUARE FEET; Theater Renovation Welcomed as a Gain For Arts in Brooklyn

body: Roulette, a performance space in SoHo that has been a longtime fixture of the downtown avant-garde music scene, is moving to Brooklyn. Roulette, which is operated by a nonprofit organization, announced on Friday that it had signed a 20-year lease on a 7,000-square-foot Art Deco concert hall at Atlantic and Third Avenues in downtown Brooklyn, a few
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Roulette Lands New Home In Brooklyn

body: It is afternoon in Brooklyn, and school has just let out. Swarms of teenagers crowd the sidewalks, looking for a place to socialize. But near Downtown Brooklyn, at the entrances to the Atlantic Terminal mall, there is no hanging out at one popular meeting spot. Students are met by security guards, who block their path, ask questions and check IDs.
title: Policy at Brooklyn Mall Limits Entry by Young Groups

Mr. Albee's delight in language takes the absurdist route here with a pair of identical 28-year-old twins named OTTO and otto (their last name is not
title: Broadway Bound and Also Unbound

body: THE history of Western classical music is rife with forgotten side roads, populated by composers and styles overlooked, marginalized or otherwise neglected. The Propensity of Sound, a five-concert series that the Issue Project Room in Gowanus, Brooklyn, will mount in late September, follows one such unfamiliar path. Presented in collaboration with
title: Dispatches From the Edge Of the Sonic Frontier

body: BROOKLYN BOOK FESTIVAL Animals, aliens, monsters, body parts (especially the posterior) and anything that's a gross-out -- these literary themes always seem to captivate children. The Brooklyn Book Festival offers them all, but its organizers also provide something for young people that many book fairs don't: titles and topics for those older than
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AS the first day of school approaches, consider the humble bulletin board. A classroom bulletin board, for those not versed in such matters, must be colorful and contain exclamation points. It must have a theme: ''We Have Classroom Harmony!'' adorned with musical notes, perhaps, or ''Up, Up and Away!'' surrounded by biplanes. In early September,
title: SUMMER RITUALS | SCHOOL SHOPPING; Filling the Cart With Expectations

body: The Dumpster divers started their bicycle run just after nightfall on a summer Friday, rolling through the steamy streets of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, stopping only to dig through trash bags and pull out produce. They wore plastic gloves for the messier bags and used a flashlight on the darker stretches of sidewalk. Then they loaded their finds
title: BROOKLYN JOURNAL; Sharing the Wealth at a Dumpster Divers' Feast

body: THE recession has not been kind to many new condominium developments in New York City. Some have stalled midconstruction; others have shuttered their sales offices because of inactivity; some developers have had to return deposits to buyers as prices took a nosedive. But two years after the real estate market seized up, some of the hardest-hit
title: Goodbye Glitz

body: Nadia Yaron, 31, left, and Myriah Scruggs, 34, right, the owners of Nightwood, a Brooklyn furniture and textile design studio, have created a pop-up shop at be@schermerhorn, a new condominium in downtown Brooklyn. The 4,000-square-foot shop, which is open through Oct. 31, carries airy, conceptual pieces that evoke the idea of shelter (like the
title: CURRENTS | OPEN; Into the Woods

body: India Day Parade and Festival (Sunday) Lower Madison Avenue will be teeming with the sights, sounds and tastes of India on Sunday at the 30th India Day Parade and Festival, commemorating the 64th anniversary of India Independence Day. The fun begins at 11 a.m. with a street fair from 23rd to 26th Streets. The first of more than 300 performers from
title: Spare Times: Around Town

body: Despite neighborhood unease, the city is moving forward with plans to fully reopen a jail in downtown Brooklyn, but has dropped plans to double its size, the city's corrections commissioner said Wednesday. The move is part of a reconfiguration of the city's jail system, which also includes the demolition of rundown buildings at Rikers Island, the
title: City Moves to Reopen a Brooklyn Jail Shuttered in 2003, but Drops Plans to Expand It

body: It's Ann Liv Young versus P.S. 1, Round 2. Ms. Young, a provocative performance artist, was at the center of a controversy in February when the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center abruptly cut the power in the middle of her appearance, plunging an already chaotic scene into darkness. Now she is planning to return to the museum, having been invited by
title: Provocative Artist Fights For Return To P.S. 1

body: DAN WOHL met Marisa Wallace on the job at the Barnes & Noble bookstore in Brooklyn Heights. She was hired to work with him in the children's department, and he was happy to show her the ropes. Two years ago, when they decided to find a place together, he was sharing an apartment with friends in Greenpoint and she was living with her family in
title: THE HUNT; An Affordable Apartment for One

body: Shira Abbie Rosenhaft and Thomas Salvatore Conoscenti were married Saturday in Brooklyn Bridge Park. The Rev. Jesse D. Hendrich, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated. The bride, 30, is keeping her name. She plans community events and coordinates media sponsorships on behalf of WNYC and WQXR, public radio stations in New York.
title: Shira Rosenhaft, Thomas Conoscenti

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Jewish Museum Thursday at 6:30 p.m., a screening of ''The Goldbergs'' (1950) by Walter Hart, based on the radio and television series ''The Goldbergs,'' which starred Gertrude Berg and featured the daily lives of a Jewish family in the Bronx; $15, $12 for students and 65+, $10 for members (includes admission to museum
title: Spare Times

body: Closing a key chapter in one of the most controversial police shootings in recent memory, New York City agreed on Tuesday to pay more than $7 million to settle a federal lawsuit filed by the family and two friends of Sean Bell, a 23-year-old black man who was fatally shot by the police in 2006 on what would have been his wedding day. The decision
title: Sean Bell Case Settled by City For $7 Million

author: Rachel Aviv is a Rosalynn Carter fellow for mental-health journalism and a frequent contributor to Education Life.
body: HANNAH WOLFE traveled to school by air last year. It required precise timing, a skill she honed when she and her friends moved to what they called Rosy -- a sprawling apartment complex on Roosevelt Island that doubles as a dorm. All her classes at Marymount Manhattan College were on the Upper East Side, and to get there, she took two buses and a
title: EMPIRE STATE OF MIND; Backpacks Among the Briefcases

body: EVERY now and again, during the six years that Mary Beth and Alan Maginn lived in a one-bedroom apartment on the ground floor of a two-family row house in Park Slope, they toyed with the idea of moving. Over time, their rent rose to $1,975 a month from $1,700. They occasionally checked online to see what else was available, only to conclude they
title: THE HUNT; Escape From Quirkyville

body: Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. Sandra Bernhard (Tuesday) Alternately beloved and reviled for her brash and wicked stand-up routines, the comedian Ms. Bernhard is not prone to blushing or biting her tongue. As a vocalist she explores pop, jazz, blues and rock in a heady, steady alto tinged with defiance; her band, the
title: The Listings

body: For years, the only involvement many retired athletes had with real estate was deciding where to open a steak house with their name on it. But some sports stars, looking for a sustainable career outside the arena, have jumped into the development game -- buying hotels, building shopping centers and renovating affordable housing, much of it in and
title: SQUARE FEET; After Sports Careers, Vying in the Real Estate Arena

body: Brooklyn is in a hotel-building boom, after decades in which the Marriott near the Brooklyn Bridge had the borough's lodging market mostly to itself. The new competitors include budget brands like Best Western, which has three locations in Brooklyn, and the Sheraton Brooklyn, which opened downtown in May. Over the last few years, Brooklyn has also
title: SQUARE FEET; As Everyone Else Has Discovered Brooklyn, So Have Hoteliers

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: A necessary clarification: It is most definitely the heat. Last Tuesday, on Fresh Pond Road in Ridgewood, Queens, the teenage girl dragging along in blue jeans and a hijab wasn't humid. The woman standing outside Shanghai City Nail, trying to juggle three shopping bags and the long folds of her shalwar kameez, wasn't either. Nor was the elderly
title: CITY CRITIC; Cool Air, if You Can Get to It

author: Kevin Walsh is the author of ''Forgotten New York: Views of a Lost Metropolis'' and the co-curator of '' Forgotten City Lights,'' a coming exhibition at the City Reliquary museum. Matteo Pericoli is an illustrator.
body: Until the 1950s a wide variety of lampposts stood along New York streets, from cast-iron Gilded Age masterpieces to humble Depression-era wood beams -- a 1934 city catalog listed 76 styles. But in the wave of postwar urban renewal, the city embarked on a wave of consolidation, trading its diversity for a monoculture based on stark octagonal
title: OP-ART; The Best and the Brightest

body: At 3 p.m. in Bryant Park on Monday, the most envied man was Thomas Tavarez. Even though he was working under the merciless sun on a national holiday and even though his uniform included a pair of rugged long pants, Mr. Tavarez had something that people slumped in the shade all around him coveted. He had a hose. With a sprinkler attachment. The
title: On a 99-Degree Day, Cooling Off by Any Means Available

body: AROUND TOWN New York City ANNUAL ALL-NIGHT WALKING TOUR OF REVOLUTIONARY WAR NEW YORK, Lower Manhattan. Led by James Kaplan. It meets Sunday at 2 a.m. at Broadway and Murray Street and ends at 6 a.m. in front of Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street, the sponsor of the walk. Fee: $20, members $15; (212) 471-8546 or (212) 425-1778. EATING CONTESTS
title: Spare Times

body: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- The battle for New York's basketball heart will begin not on the hot asphalt of Manhattan or on a bustling Brooklyn street corner, but in a quiet quadrant of northeast Ohio. At 12:01 a.m. Thursday, a small regiment of Nets officials, led by their swaggering new owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, will march into a meeting room
title: Nets and Knicks Ready For a Pilgrimage to Ohio

body: Mr. Chera, 67, is a founder of Crown Acquisitions, which has an ownership interest in dozens of retail and office properties throughout North America, including trophy buildings in Manhattan like the Fred F. French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue and the retail space at 666 Fifth and the St. Regis Hotel. Q How's business? A Great. Q Better than last
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Stanley Chera

body: Starting today, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will eliminate dozens of bus lines and cut service on many more as part of its effort to close a budget gap approaching $800 million. The service cuts elicited howls of protests from riders at public hearings, but the agency said it had little choice. Here is a roundup of route closings, and
title: As M.T.A. Cuts Bus Service, a Look at Who Rides Where

body: Over the last decade, a growing stream of the young, the stylish and the family-oriented have been drawn to Brooklyn by its parks, waterfront, cultural life and relatively affordable real estate and acres of graceful brownstones. But when it comes time for those newcomers to have their babies, they are tied as if by an umbilical cord to Manhattan.
title: A Manhattan Birth Certificate, But an Address in Brooklyn

body: Rod Thorn, the Nets' president and the architect of their N.B.A. finals teams in 2002 and 2003, has told the team that he has decided to step down from the position he has held since 2000. Thorn, 69, has been offered a contract to stay on with the team by the team's new owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, but has been wrestling with the decision to make a
title: Nets' Thorn Is Said to Be Planning to Step Down

body: IF there were such a thing as a punk-rock festival checklist, an event taking place in downtown Brooklyn this weekend would cross off all the items. Seminal band? Check. Accompanying skate park? Check. Vendors offering the latest gear? Check. In addition to those requisite markers, this one has one more: diversity. Welcome to the Afro-Punk
title: Punk Fans Find A Home in Brooklyn

body: The scene was 125th Street, but a very different sort of ''Showtime at the Apollo'' played out on Wednesday morning. Harlem is about to get its first new hotel in decades, and 75 or so applicants hoping to land a job there mingled on a soundstage at the Apollo Theater wearing brightly colored leis, sang along to Michael Jackson videos and
title: Casting Call (Smile!) For a Hotel In Harlem

body: ''Four days ago this was nothing; that wall didn't exist,'' an ebullient Charles Gibb, the president of Belvedere Vodka, said on a recent night as he pointed to a pristine white wall in a meatpacking district space covered with images of a model wearing a citrus-pink caftan. Nearby, the comedian Chelsea Handler chatted with admirers while sipping a
title: SQUARE FEET; Very Brief Tenants, and Why Landlords Like Them

body: Unlike his outsize real estate undertaking in downtown Brooklyn, Bruce C. Ratner blends in. In the commercial heart of the neighborhood that he is reshaping and where many are said to resent him, Ratner walked the perimeter of the footprint for his $1 billion sports arena during a recent weekday lunch hour without drawing a glance. Maybe this was
title: Building Success in the Shadows

body: The controversial 38-story tower that New York University seeks to add to its University Village complex in Greenwich Village would be made of concrete with floor-to-ceiling windows on the Bleecker Street side, according to plans, above, made public Thursday by the university. The design by Grimshaw Architects, published in The Wall Street Journal,
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; N.Y.U. Shows Plan For Tower

body: Mr. Capoccia, 55, is a managing principal and founder of BFC Partners, which has developed 4,500 housing units throughout the New York area. The company's projects include the recently completed Toren, a 240-unit condominium in downtown Brooklyn, and Schaefer Landing, a three-building waterfront complex in nearby Williamsburg. Q How are sales at
title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Donald A. Capoccia

body: Any art lover can visit a museum, but the more adventurous can take to the streets for the New York City Department of Transportation's free bike tour on Saturday. From 9:30 a.m. to noon, a guide will lead cyclists across Manhattan to murals, sculptures and mosaics sponsored by the Urban Art Program, an effort to invigorate the city's streetscapes.
title: WEEKEND MISER; A Bike Tour for Art Lovers, a Show for 'Fela!' Fans, Capoeira Lessons and a Korean Film

body: Week to week. That's how the great state of New York is making do during these sorry days of fiscal ridiculousness. Since the state has seen fit to get along without an annual budget, an emergency spending bill gets approved every week authorizing just enough money to enable New York to squeeze through the next seven days. One of these weeks, well,
title: In These Difficult Times, New York State's Motto Could Be: Will Tattoo for Food

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER (Sunday and Tuesday) The company returns to Brooklyn with old favorites and the first performance in 35 years of Ailey's ''Mary Lou's Mass,'' commemorating the centennial of the birth of its composer, Mary Lou Williams. (Through June 20.) Sunday at 3
title: The Listings

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Q.The Tony Awards will be held next Sunday. So who was Tony? A. Broadway's major honors are formally the Antoinette Perry Awards, given since 1947 for distinguished achievement in the theater. They were founded by the American Theater Wing. Ms. Perry, right, was an actress who turned to directing after she was partly paralyzed by a stroke. At the
title: F.Y.I.; The Antoinette Awards

body: You don't have to be a baseball pitcher from Detroit throwing the game of your life to get robbed in the big city. Heck, you don't even have to play baseball to get robbed, cheated, wronged -- to have your own perfect little game called life on any particular day botched by that great and menacing and half-blind umpire that is New York. On
title: A Perfect Game? Too Bad. But in New York, Everybody Gets Robbed.

(Through June 20.) At 7:30 p.m., Brooklyn
title: The Listings

body: Dips and Grills 101 A class in preparing hors d'oeuvres, including zucchini fritters with yogurt-cucumber dip, will be given on June 7 from 6 to 7 p.m. at Thalassa, 179 Franklin Street (Hudson Street). A dessert class will be given on June 14. Reservations, $75 a class: (212) 941-7661. A class in summer grilling, covering kosher cuts of steak and
title: Calendar

body: A hotel row grows in Brooklyn. The 25-story Sheraton Brooklyn New York Hotel opened on May 20 in the shadow of the MetroTech Center and Brooklyn Academy of Music, the first of several hotels scheduled to open in the area. The Sheraton (228 Duffield Street; 718-855-1900; sheratonbrooklyn.com) has 321 modern rooms and suites, a large fitness center,
title: IN TRANSIT; Downtown Brooklyn Gets a Sheraton

body: THOUGH Willie Holmes had been traveling back and forth to New York for a few years, primarily for modeling jobs, he had little knowledge of the city's housing market -- just vague impressions from his New York friends, most of whom lived in Harlem. After six years in the Army, he was ready to relocate to New York, in order to further his modeling
title: THE HUNT; A Home In Brooklyn, On the G.I. Bill

body: WITH the unofficial start of summer this weekend, there are several hot tickets to be had. But to get to the front of the line, you need to know your way around. The Public Theater's Shakespeare in the Park returns on June 9, with ''The Winter's Tale'' and ''The Merchant of Venice'' being performed in repertory. Most New Yorkers know the drill: on
title: To Get Those Summer Tickets, Strategize

Cara Sadownick, Corcoran Group (917) 710-6504; www.corcoran.com Open house Sunday, 1 to 3 p.m.
title: ON THE MARKET

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: We may never see this man again, but for one shining moment Mikhail D. Prokhorov gave hope -- not necessarily for the star-crossed Nets basketball franchise, but for the entire species of sports owners. Only hours after seeing his chance for the top draft pick thwarted by a fateful lottery, Prokhorov was downright entertaining -- a word not
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; A New Owner Makes A Winning Impression

body: Brooklyn, the new bastion of cool for many New Yorkers, is poised to go mainstream chic. The announcement that Barneys Co-op will open its first store in Cobble Hill has cleared the way for other nationally recognized high-end retailers to make a similar move across the bridge, according to brokers who specialize in representing luxury clothiers.
title: SQUARE FEET; High-End Retailers Are Scouting Sites in Brooklyn

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: HITTING 30 was a turning point for Andy Lagrimas. He was more than ready to rent a place of his own. Before that, to afford Manhattan, he found it necessary to share an apartment. But ''I made a resolution when I turned 30 to say goodbye to roommates,'' said Mr. Lagrimas, who reached that milestone last fall. ''I felt too old to be doing the
title: THE HUNT; My Roommate? Me, Myself and I

body: THE government program that allows qualified people to buy homes with very little money down is gaining traction in New York. The loans, offered through the Federal Housing Administration and available since 1934, provided 1 percent of the home loans in the region in 2007, but the number jumped to around 18 percent in 2009. As credit tightened,
title: POSTING; Demand Grows for F.H.A. Mortgages

body: It was early in the class, in a nondescript room on Union Square, where more than a dozen business managers had gathered to learn the hospitality secrets that have made Danny Meyer one of the nation's most successful restaurateurs. The moment to share had arrived. Susan Reilly Salgado, a managing director of Mr. Meyer's Union Square Hospitality
title: Spreading His Gospel Of Warm And Fuzzy

body: For the past six years, Daniel Goldstein has been at the center of just about every rally, house party, concert and lawsuit opposed to the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn. He wielded a bullhorn and had a lightning-fast e-mail response to every incursion by the developer Bruce C. Ratner on the 22-acre project site at
title: For $3 Million, A Project's Foe Ends His Fight

body: The real estate firm Two Trees Management is expanding the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn, adding a greater diversity of programming to a mix that already includes visual art and performances. The festival will now be organized by a variety of arts professionals, rather than solely by the Dumbo Arts Center, which founded it. The festival, entering
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Festival Grows

body: The Brooklyn neighborhood of Red Hook may be most famous these days for affordable Swedish design, but a group of artists is giving the once rough-and-tumble peninsula a softer, more creative edge. Their fondness for turning salvaged objects into objets d'art makes the area feel like ''a small town of misfit toys,'' in one resident's words, which
title: LOCAL STOP | RED HOOK; Past a Blue and Yellow Box, Lots of Art

body: He had fired a bullet into his parole officer's upper chest on Thursday evening, the police said, and now Robert Morales was aiming at the officer's face and trying to pull the trigger again to kill the officer, which would probably send him back to prison for good. That, the police said, is what Mr. Morales, 50, told investigators after he was
title: Frustration May Have Led Parolee to Shoot Officer

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE Saturday and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., a celebration of the Egyptian presence on Staten Island, featuring an arts and photography display and dance performances. On Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., the first of several monthly screenings highlighting the International Black Film Festival; the film will be
title: Spare Times

body: A paroled murderer walked up to his parole officer in a state office in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday evening and shot him in the shoulder, the authorities said. The parolee, Robert Morales, 50, of Hancock Street in Brooklyn, sat waiting for his name to be called in the parole office, at 333 Schermerhorn Street, all the while concealing a
title: Paroled Murderer Shoots His Parole Officer at His Desk in Brooklyn

body: Morton Feldman's String Quartet No. 2 is hardly standard fare for a housewarming. Composed in 1983, the work runs more than six hours when played complete. But somehow it seemed ideally suited for the first public event mounted by Issue Project Room, a vital avant-garde performing arts presenter, in its future home at 110 Livingston Street in
title: MUSIC REVIEW; An All-Day Concert, but Only One Piece Was Performed

title: Spare Times

body: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a basketball-loving Russian billionaire who is expected to be approved as the majority owner of the Nets next month, moved into the American spotlight Sunday with a profile on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' In an interview with Steve Kroft, Prokhorov said, ''I am real excited to take the worst team of the league and turn it to be the
title: Nets' Likely Owner Faces a Nation

body: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- For a late-season matchup of teams whose combined winning percentages do not add up to .500, Friday night's Nets-Pistons game at the Izod Center had an unmistakable air of consequence, the scent of history in the unmaking. Before a surprisingly festive crowd of 13,469, Brook Lopez scored 37 points and Yi Jianlian added 31
title: NETS 118, PISTONS 110; Another Win Puts Nets Step Further From History

body: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) Friday CHURCH OF ST. IGNATIUS OF ANTIOCH (Episcopal), 552 West End
title: Beyond the Bunny: Bach and Organs and Sacred Songs

body: Anderson Cooper, the CNN anchor, has drawn attention for his plans to turn a former West Village firehouse into a private residence. Preservationists want landmark designation for the building; a man whose son worked at the firehouse and died in the Sept. 11 attacks wants Mr. Cooper to restore a memorial plaque; and an architect working on the
title: At Home in a Firehouse: Some Helpful Hints for Anderson Cooper

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Saturday, 1 to 5:30 p.m. and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m., New York's Latino communities are explored with ''From the Motherlands to El Barrio: New York's Latino Immigrant Experience.'' Highlights include ''Holding Up the Sky,'' a Mayan creation story by the Coatlicue Theater Company;
title: Spare Times

author: Andrew Cotto lives in Carroll Gardens and teaches composition, over the racket of jackhammers, at the ASA Institute in Downtown Brooklyn. Join a reader discussion of his rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: WE left Manhattan for Brooklyn in 1997. Even then, before it was the rage, it felt like a destination. We kept track of all the things the neighborhoods of Brooklyn had over the metropolis of Manhattan: actual diversity, affordable restaurants, more parking and less pretension. But the best thing, no doubt, every time, was the sky. Brooklyn had
title: COMPLAINT BOX BROOKLYN RISING; They're Stealing My Sky

body: For Robert Carrizzo, the daily commute from his Midtown office to the Staten Island Ferry is typically filled with precise rituals. But there is always one irritating question mark: the cost of the taxi ride. The price of what should be a short and fairly standard trip is like the price of a volatile stock. It is never the same and frequently
title: Do Passengers Believe Cabbies Cheat Them? Are Taxicabs Yellow?

body: Speaking before a church congregation in Brooklyn, Gov. David A. Paterson declared on Sunday that he was the victim of innuendo and lies and that he would finish his term to ''fulfill the mission in which God placed me.'' Talking for 15 minutes to a sympathetic and largely black audience at the Cornerstone Baptist Church, Mr. Paterson energetically
title: Paterson Says Governing Is the Task God Gave Him

body: For a team that has won 6 of its 61 games this season, the future is all the Nets have. On Friday, they celebrated their anticipated two-year layover at the Prudential Center with a news conference followed by a one-on-one matchup between Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark and Darryl Dawkins, the former Nets center, on a halfcourt set up inside one of
title: Nets Laud Future Newark Home as a Bridge to Brooklyn

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com
body: It could have been any late-winter afternoon in Downtown Brooklyn: the sun bright, people grabbing lunch from hot-dog carts, traffic rolling along Tillary Street. But it happened to be Monday of this week, and inside the federal courthouse at Cadman Plaza, a man was led into a courtroom. His name was Najibullah Zazi, and last summer he was caught
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Terrorist In Court? Life Goes On

body: Hunched over their computers on a recent afternoon, two brothers were sketching plans to build a green roof for an elementary school in Brooklyn. One row and three desks away, a woman was working on an environmentally friendly fashion project, a little black dress that can be worn 365 ways. Nearby, an information technology consultant was briefing
title: At Shared Offices, How Green Is My Work Space

body: When Frankie Garriga talks about what the Morris Park Boxing Club has meant to him, he takes on the air of Marlon Brando's slightly punchy Terry Malloy in ''On the Waterfront.'' Boxing, he hopes, will make him a somebody. ''A lot of people show me a lot of respect because I'm a Golden Gloves champion,'' said Mr. Garriga, a wiry 21-year-old who
title: MORRIS PARK JOURNAL; Seeking to Save a Gym That Saved Young Lives

Also Saturday, at 7:30 and 9 p.m., performances by the group Songs of the Sea & Taverns; part of the Tavern Concert Series; $15; $12 for members; reservations required: (718) 351-1611, Ext. 281. title: Spare Times

body: The afternoon court session grew more heated in its final hour. Michael Mineo, who prosecutors say was sodomized with a police officer's baton during a stop, faced tough questions about the extent of his injuries and whether he remembered the color of his blood. In the middle of that critical testimony, a lawyer for the officer requested a recess.
title: Amid Drama of Police Trial, a Judge Unfazed

title: Spare Times

body: To the woman who found a knapsack outside the federal courthouse in Brooklyn on Thursday, taking it to the courthouse's lost and found office might have seemed like a simple act of courtesy. But to courthouse officials, the unattended bag was potentially dangerous. When they put it through a scanning machine around noon, they saw a laptop computer
title: Suspicious Backpack Leads to Courthouse Evacuation

body: Stuart London, a defense lawyer, wasted little time on pleasantries as he greeted Michael Mineo on the witness stand just after 10 a.m. Tuesday. ''Good morning, Mr. Mineo, how are you?'' Mr. London said. ''You didn't get stoned today before you came to court, did you?'' A prosecutor immediately objected to the question, and Mr. Mineo, who
title: Hostile Grilling and Angry Witness Mark Officers' Trial in Abuse Case

body: In court, Michael Mineo told the story of his troubled young life, reciting the wrongs he had committed against others, and those he said had been visited upon him. But Mr. Mineo, 25, insisted that he was telling the truth when he spoke about what police officers did to him in a Brooklyn subway station on Oct. 15, 2008. That day, he testified,
title: Man Testifies That Police Brutalized Him in a Brooklyn Subway Station

body: THE view from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, a five-block walkway that has overlooked New York Harbor from its perch at neighborhood's edge since 1950, is almost the same as it was 60 years ago. The Lower Manhattan skyline rises up, seeming close enough to touch, against a backdrop of clouds; tugboats push barges to and fro; cars and trucks race
title: LIVING IN | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The 360 From Here

body: SCORES of stalled construction projects can be found scattered around New York City, but one category of building that doesn't seem to have been sidetracked by the recession is the luxury apartment rental. At least 16 new rental buildings are expected to open in Manhattan in coming months, ranging from small buildings to 500-unit high-rises, for a
title: 2010: The Year of the Renter?

body: A decade ago, during jury selection in the case of the police officers accused of torturing Abner Louima, thousands of people marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to protest abuses by the police. In 2007, outside a courthouse in Queens, New Black Panthers and police union members made up the cast of vocal partisans watching the trial of the officers
title: Trial Into Claims of Police Brutality on a Subway Platform Opens Without Uproar

body: Comrades, comrades. Alex Steinberg, a late-middle-aged self-described revolutionary Socialist in a pullover sweater, attempted to bring to order to the board of WBAI, also known as ''free-speech radio.'' And even better known as New York City's last FM outpost of lefty, vegan, hip-hop, poetry-reading and -- often but not invariably --
title: 99.5 FM, Where the Board Meetings Make the Broadcasts Seem Tame

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Through Aug. 15, ''Traveling the Silk Road: Ancient Pathway to the Modern World''; in conjunction with the exhibition, Saturday and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m., ''Voices of the Silk Road,'' with performances by musicians from Ukraine, Tibet, Uzbekistan, the Krygyz Republic and other
title: Spare Times

body: Eating spiced lamb at a bustling Yemeni restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn, Mahib Alkrizy said that since Sept. 11, 2001, his wife, a religious Muslim who covers her hair, has come to expect being patted down and stared at when she travels by plane. Around the corner at Abu Yasser Travel Agency, employees waved a reporter away -- they were tired of
title: For Immigrants, New Travel Concerns

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Thursday at 6:30 p.m., ''Curry Economics: Food as a Driving Force of Economic Development,'' a discussion with scholars, writers and food experts; $15; $13.50 for students, members and 60+. Through May 31, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' featuring
title: Spare Times

body: Bill de Blasio, New York City's new public advocate, is a lifelong Democrat and a likely future mayoral contender. But ask him to name the most innovative political force in the state, and he points to the Working Families Party. ''On the issues they care about, from minimum wage to tenant issues to development, they are absolutely definitional --
title: As Clout Grows, Working Families Party Faces a Question: Has It Reached Too Far?

body: Ahmed Nasser Yemen Ahmed Nasser was a young recruit in March 2000, one of three people of Arab descent in his Police Academy class, he recalled, and one of about 20 in the entire department. At times, his culture could feel singular to him. He recalled his first assignment, in Brooklyn's 76th Precinct, and how he spent quiet moments on lunch breaks
title: From Around the Globe, Officers Serving New York

body: Ahmed Nasser Yemen Ahmed Nasser was a young recruit in March 2000, one of three people of Arab descent in his Police Academy class, he recalled, and one of about 20 in the entire department. At times, his culture could feel singular to him. He recalled his first assignment, in Brooklyn's 76th Precinct, and how he spent quiet moments on lunch breaks
title: From Around the Globe, Officers Serving New York

body: Palita Gbalajobi wants to work, and she will push her body to the brink to do it. ''I can't see nothing at all, just down,'' she said one afternoon in her living room in Canarsie, Brooklyn, covering her good eye. Ms. Gbalajobi, (pronounced Jeh-ba-la-jo-bi) 70, does not let partial blindness stop her from seeking work. ''I really need a job,'' she
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Woman's Desire to Work Is Thwarted by a Body That Strains to Keep Up

body: In Wednesday's Dining section, Sam Sifton, the restaurant critic for The Times, reviewed Purple Yam, a Filipino restaurant in Ditmas Park with inspiration from across Asia. He described it as ''a perfect neighborhood restaurant'' and awarded it one star, then asked readers for their favorite neighborhood spots. Here are a few (many more are online
title: Diner's Journal

body: If off-track betting collided with Broadway, the combination might emit the kind of roar coming from inside the TKTS booth in Times Square, where discounted theater seats are sold. Desperate faces plastered against windows give wads of $20 bills to no-nonsense cashiers who bark the names of shows as if they were taking bets on the ponies: ''No 'In
title: It Might Be Your Ticket, if the Show's in New York
